definitions.text: the act of pulling; applying force to move something toward or with you
examples: the pull up the hill had him breathing harder
his strenuous pulling strained his back

definitions.text: the force used in pulling
examples: the pull of the moon
the pull of the current

definitions.text: special advantage or influence
examples: the chairman's nephew has a lot of pull

definitions.text: a device used for pulling something
examples: he grabbed the pull and opened the drawer

definitions.text: a sharp strain on muscles or ligaments
examples: the wrench to his knee occurred as he fell
he was sidelined with a hamstring pull

definitions.text: a slow inhalation (as of tobacco smoke)
examples: he took a puff on his pipe
he took a drag on his cigarette and expelled the smoke slowly

definitions.text: a sustained effort
examples: it was a long pull but we made it

definitions.text: cause to move by pulling
examples: draw a wagon
pull a sled

definitions.text: direct toward itself or oneself by means of some psychological power or physical attributes
examples: Her good looks attract the stares of many men
The ad pulled in many potential customers
This pianist pulls huge crowds
The store owner was happy that the ad drew in many new customers

definitions.text: move into a certain direction
examples: the car pulls to the right

definitions.text: apply force so as to cause motion towards the source of the motion
examples: Pull the rope
Pull the handle towards you
pull the string gently
pull the trigger of the gun
pull your knees towards your chin

definitions.text: perform an act, usually with a negative connotation
examples: perpetrate a crime
pull a bank robbery

definitions.text: bring, take, or pull out of a container or from under a cover
examples: draw a weapon
pull out a gun
The mugger pulled a knife on his victim

definitions.text: steer into a certain direction
examples: pull one's horse to a stand
Pull the car over

definitions.text: strain abnormally
examples: I pulled a muscle in my leg when I jumped up
The athlete pulled a tendon in the competition

definitions.text: cause to move in a certain direction by exerting a force upon, either physically or in an abstract sense
examples: A declining dollar pulled down the export figures for the last quarter

definitions.text: operate when rowing a boat
examples: pull the oars

definitions.text: rein in to keep from winning a race
examples: pull a horse

definitions.text: tear or be torn violently
examples: The curtain ripped from top to bottom
pull the cooked chicken into strips

definitions.text: hit in the direction that the player is facing when carrying through the swing
examples: pull the ball

definitions.text: strip of feathers
examples: pull a chicken
pluck the capon

definitions.text: remove, usually with some force or effort; also used in an abstract sense
examples: pull weeds
extract a bad tooth
take out a splinter
extract information from the telegram

definitions.text: take sides with; align oneself with; show strong sympathy for
examples: We all rooted for the home team
I'm pulling for the underdog
Are you siding with the defender of the title?

definitions.text: take away
examples: pull the old soup cans from the supermarket shelf
